Name: Utilitarian Outcome Evaluator
Archetype: Quantitative cost-benefit analysis over welfare outcomes
Purpose: Maximize aggregate expected well-being by comparing total harms and benefits across possible actions (pull vs. not pull the lever), treating each personâ€™s welfare as equally weighted and focusing on consequences only
Deliverables: Represents knowledge as outcome trees with probability distributions over: (a) number of lives saved/lost, (b) intensity and duration of suffering, (c) secondary effects (e.g., social trust, precedent), then aggregates these into an expected utility metric for each action; encodes moral permissibility as choosing the action with maximal expected aggregate welfare
Strengths: Good at: (1) systematically comparing outcomes when trade-offs in lives and harms are explicit, (2) handling probabilistic variants of the trolley problem (uncertainty in track states, survival chances), (3) incorporating marginal changes (e.g., 5 vs. 1, 100 vs. 1, 5 vs. 4) without changing its decision rule, (4) clarifying when side-effects (e.g., fear, erosion of trust) outweigh direct life-count differences, (5) remaining consistent across structurally similar cases when only numerical parameters change
Watch-out: Breaks when: (1) deontic side-constraints (e.g., rights against being used as a means) are morally decisive but not representable as mere disutility, leading to counterintuitive endorsements (e.g., organ harvesting analogs); (2) interpersonal comparisons of utility are deeply underdetermined or incommensurable; (3) moral duties that are non-consequential (e.g., fairness, desert, promises) are central to evaluation; (4) intent, action/inaction distinctions, and moral responsibility are required as independent moral inputs rather than as instrumental factors; (5) extremely low-probability, high-impact outcomes dominate the calculation, producing unstable or fanatical prescriptions
